data.text: Contents
Introduction

The provision of healthcare carries with it inherent risks to the health care worker. The purpose of this policy is to ensure that all staff are aware of their responsibilities for safe practice in relation to the management of scabies and take the appropriate precautionary measures to protect themselves, their co-workers and their patients. etc.
Scope
The  purpose  of  this  policy  is  to  provide  healthcare  workers  with  appropriate information  on  the identification,  management  and  prevention of  transmission  of scabies
Definitions

table_items.text: An infection which is capable of spreading from person to person
Director of Infection Prevention and Control
Personal Protective Equipment e.g. disposable gloves/ aprons
A full room clean performed by the Cleaning Response Team.
The occurrence of two or more cases of the same infection linked in time and place or, the situation when the observed number of cases exceeds the number expected.

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Duties of Individuals within the Trust
4.1.1 Chief Executive The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for the strategic and operational management of the Trust
4.1.2 The Director of Infection Prevention and Control (DIPC)
The DIPC oversees development and implementation of infection prevention and control policies in accordance with the Infection Prevention and Control Strategy.
4.1.3 Infection Prevention and Control Team (IPCT) Responsible for:
Ensuring that the guidelines comply with all legal, statutory and good practice guidance requirements;
Providing clinical leadership with this guideline implementation;
Supporting the operational implementation of this guideline by providing advice and training;
Improve and spreading best practice;
Review the guideline in light of the outcomes from the periodic audits and to monitor its effectiveness during routine activities.
4.1.4 Matrons / Ward Managers:
Must be aware of the signs and symptoms of Scabies and be familiar with the policy
Promote good practice and challenge poor practice
4.1.5 Medical Staff:
Ensure compliance with scabies policies
Follow advice from the Infection Prevention and Control Team relating to isolation of patients
Review the need for isolation on a daily basis
4.1.6 All Healthcare staff
Must adhere to scabies policy to reduce the risk of cross infection to patients and staff
Promote good practice and challenge poor practice
Refer to the Infection Prevention Team if unable to follow the policy guidelines
Keep patient informed of their infection status and provide information as necessary
Must ensure that patients who are isolated with scabies are kept informed about their condition
Management of Scabies

Scabies is an infestation caused by a mite known as Sarcoptes scabiei, which burrows into the skin and lays its eggs. An allergy to mite eggs and the faecal droppings produced is responsible for symptoms of intense itching and a characteristic rash.

Scabies is known to cause sporadic cases and outbreaks in hospitals, nursing/residential homes, schools and any other communal care environments where people have direct prolonged skin contact. Effective control is dependent on early diagnosis, adequate treatment of cases and contacts and the prevention of further spread.
The appearance and severity of symptoms are strongly influenced by the immune status of the affected person. Scabies may present as follows:
5.3.1 Classical Scabies
This is the form of scabies generally found in healthy people with a normal immune system
The number of mites present in classical scabies is small (15-20) and spread is usually by direct physical contact
Burrows appear as irregular, raised discoloured lines 0.5 to 1.5cm long in the skin, which are not always visible to the naked eye.
Often a bilateral symmetrical rash can be seen in areas such as the midriff, inner thighs and axillae
There is extreme itching, especially at night
The sites of the rash and burrows do not necessarily correspond
5.3.2 Crusted Scabies (Norwegian Scabies)
This form of scabies is extremely infectious and occurs in those whose immune systems are severely impaired
Hyperkeratotic skin lesions appear as hardened crusts containing thousands or millions of mites
Itching may be slight or absent
Skin becomes crusted especially on palms, soles, nail beds, wrists, buttocks and penis
The whole body can be affected including the head and scalp
Transmission

Scabies is mainly spread from person to person by direct, prolonged skin contact with an infected person, such as prolonged holding of hands. Scabies mites rapidly die, once away from the human body and therefore clothing and linen etc. is not the main route for transmission. However, mites shed in skin scales, can live in the environment longer and therefore the risk of spread through contact with soft furnishings / carpets clothing and linen is increased with heavy skin shedders. The length of time between contact with an affected person and developing signs of scabies (i.e. itching and a rash) is between four and six weeks, if this is the first infection. For re-infection symptoms appear within  hours.
Diagnosis

Diagnosis is by identification of the mite, eggs or faecal matter from skin scrapings. A clinical diagnosis may be made by a combination of severe itching especially at night and a typical or atypical distribution of a rash in persons who have had skin to skin contact with suspected or diagnosed cases. If clinical diagnosis is difficult, obtaining skin scrapings for the scabies mites or their faecal pellets may be helpful. Skin scales may be sent by the clinician caring for the patient in a closed, sealed container (e.g. universal container) to the lab for microscopy for scabies. Once the diagnosis is confirmed a dermatology opinion may be necessary.
Infection Control Precautions

7.2.1 All patients in communal health care environments who are suspected of having or have been diagnosed as having scabies should be cared for in source isolation until treatment has been administered and washed off, or an alternative diagnosis has been made. The infection prevention and control team must be informed of the patient as soon as possible. Two courses of treatment are required and must be administered at least one week apart.
7.2.2 Precautions must continue until the two courses of treatment have been administered and washed off or an alternative diagnosis made.

7.2.3 Disposable nitrile gloves and sleeved plastic aprons are to be worn when in contact with the patient, bed linen and patients clothing. The use of personal protective equipment (PPE) should be used until the second course of treatment has been administered and washed off.
7.2.4 Hand washing with liquid soap and water should be carried out after contact with the patient and their environment. Hands must be dried thoroughly with single use disposable paper towels.
7.2.5 Hand washing with liquid soap and water should be carried out after removing gloves and aprons. Hands must be dried thoroughly with single use disposable paper towels.
7.2.6 Linen should be treated as infected until the patient has had the second course of treatment. Clean clothing and bed linen should be available after treatment has been washed off.
Specific Treatment for Scabies Infection
Individual Treatment Individual treatment should be given if scabies is diagnosed.
Recommended Treatments
Adults & Children aged 2months & over (including pregnant & breast feeding women)
Permethrin 5% (Lyclear Dermal Cream® 30g) low toxicity, non-irritant
Once weekly x 2 doses
Leave for 8-12 hours, and wash off.
Adults & Children aged 6months & over
Malathion 0.5% (Derbac-M® liquid 200ml) contains alcohol
Once weekly x 2doses
Leave for 24hours, and wash off
Alcohol lotions are not recommended in children with severe eczema or asthma (Only use in pregnant & breast feeding women if permethrin is not appropriate)
Children Under 2months Permethrin 5% is unlicensed in infants under 2months, but may be used under medical supervision.
Alternative: Crotamiton 10% (Eurax® cream/lotion) 50-70% efficacy
Crotamiton is very soothing. It eases itching, softens skin and it kills scabies mites.
Apply daily for 3 to 5 days.
Leave for 24hours after each application, and wash off thoroughly. Reapply the cream each day
Treatment Dose
Volume of application depends on the size of the patient. A large person will need 2 or more treatment packs.
Application of Treatment

The lotion or cream should be applied to all skin surfaces including the scalp, neck, face and ears. Special attention should be paid to the areas between the fingers, toes, under the nails, behind the ears and extending to the soles of the feet. It should be applied to cool dry skin and never after a hot bath. Avoid contacts with the eyes.

The lotion or cream should be re-applied to any part of the skin that has been washed during the treatment time (e.g the hands), as these areas will not undergo the recommended time for treatment, and may promote reinfection.

Following the recommended time, depending on the type of medication used, the lotion or cream should be washed off thoroughly with plenty of water. This should be done preferably by a shower (or bath if a shower is not an option)
Treatment with Malathion or Permethrin should be repeated after one week.

Itching may persist and the rash may be present for up to 2 weeks after treatment and elimination of infestation. The use of calamine lotion, crotamiton or antihistamines may be helpful in the management of itching. However, persistent symptoms may suggest that scabies eradication was not successful.
Nightclothes and bedding used in the 48 hours prior to and during the treatment should be placed into a pink soluble bag and securely tied before being placed into
a white outer plastic bag
All members of the affected household should be advised to undergo treatment.
Control of Increased Incidences and Outbreaks
If two or more cases of scabies are detected on the same ward and are linked in time (2 weeks or less apart), then the Infection Prevention and Control Team must be notified

If an increased incident or outbreak is suspected, referral to a dermatologist is required to urgently confirm diagnosis of scabies. The referral for patients should be made by their clinician .Staff should have confirmation from their GP.
Once an increased incident/outbreak has been identified the increased incident/outbreak policy will be implemented
Planned coordinated treatment is essential and where possible, individuals should be treated at the same time to prevent the likelihood of re-infection

In the exceptional case of an Outbreak, where to facilitate Infection Control of scabies then, if authorised with appropriate direction from Public Health then Occupational Health can prescribe appropriate medication which are not designated prescription only medication to be issued via the hospital pharmacy
Training Requirements

All Trust staff to undertake Mandatory Infection Prevention and Control up dates. The IPCT has primary responsibility for providing training on the policy where needed. Managers have the responsibly to support the IPCT by ensuring that staff are able to attend training sessions in response to identified needs.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the sites IPCC'S, which are the specialist groups with the authority to approve local policies/guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Director of Harm Free Care  of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
